candidate_text:
And with the increasing number of people living with diabetes, it’s more important than ever...
By Dima Alkousa August 31, 2021 in Health-tech Startups | 4 comments

What do you get when you cross an artificial intelligence (AI) startup with a neurostimulation company?

Remembering to check your blood sugar levels, recording every bit of food intake, exercise and glucose reading manually on paper logs might seem old school as everything in life is going digitalized nowadays.
That's where continuous glucose monitoring (CGM) can step in and make things so much easier.
That’s why the new technology advancements focused around diabetes care have been a significant shift.
Paper-based logs that need to daily entries can quickly feel like a hassle, leading some people stop using them altogether.
Writing down your sugar levels multiple times a day and trying to make sense of all those numbers can lead to confusion.

Here are a few suggestions:

    If you're having trouble setting and tracking your diabetes health goals, 
1) Get organized using a planner or diary: 
For each month take notes on how often you:
a] Check blood sugar level 
b] Exercise and duration/frequency of those workouts 
c] Count carbohydrates

This can even get your care partner motivated as they may wish to stay on course and achieve healthy lifestyle goals.
I mean, recording food, calculating portions, keeping tabs on medication.
The thought alone can feel overwhelming; carrying around a planner or remembering which numbers go into which columns just to keep your levels within the normal boundaries.
Keeping an accurate logbook of meals, snacks; blood sugar numbers before you sleep in an after sleep and at meal times is just too much trouble and often leads to mistakes or forgetful instances.

With continuous glucose monitors (CGMs), like FreeStyle Libre, or continuous subcutaneous insulin infusion with real-time data analytics technology in use, diabetes care has seen significant advancements.
You need to remember to log your blood glucose levels, medication dosages, and any side effects you may be experiencing.
Fortunately, diabetes apps help take some of that load off our shoulders (no pun intended).
Between testing, glucose levels multiple times per day, tracking carbohydrate intake, and recording all of your data it can be time consuming and frustrating to ensure accuracy.
From carb counting and glucose tracking to logging doses and doctor's appointments, there’s a lot to remember.
I have to take my medications every morning and night at certain hours.
I also need to eat a balanced diet that includes foods with a low glycemic index, such as whole grains, vegetables, fruits, and nuts.
It means remembering all this constantly.
The app has helped me greatly because I receive reminders and can keep track of my dosage without making mistakes,” says Shah.
Also every after every meal I have measure glucose level so it gets confusing sometimes especially when you miss one of them.
My insulin pump has specific times for each dose too.
Also taking blood glucose measurements multiple times a day is an added responsibility.
Some meds need me to record their dosage; others should only be taken at exact amounts to work effectively.
I also must log my food, exercise, blood glucose levels, and any additional details related to my health so my endo knows what going on.
So I found ways to make these responsibilities as seamless and efficient as possible through the wonders of AI!
It requires constant checking as well in terms of my blood sugar, exercise levels, etc.
In addition, tracking glucose levels has become much easier now that glucose meters are designed for simplicity.
If I forget one of these doses it messes with my entire day and week even because then we have adjustments we have to make so that doesn't mess up the future stuff."
It gets really frustrating, forget to update the log with blood glucose level after taking insulin shot...it makes me question if I did inject and when was the last time i injected the previous shot.
However, I often worry that I might forget one of my doses.
And if I don’t do this consistently over 90 days, it invalidates all of my readings.
And I also have to prick myself daily and test my glucose levels.
Missing the timing by even an hour would throw everything off balance.

Now that we're in the realm of wearables being a possibility for monitoring health aspects, you think there should be an option available to integrate such wearable information into apps that make maintaining control on diabetes easier?
Yes!

As an end-user interested in innovative advancements within healthcare, I believe it's crucial for us to discuss the potential of AI-assisted medical technology becoming incorporated directly into mobile and IoT devices.

With a small device embedded within a smartwatch-like product which sends updates regarding insulin dosages received in comparison to food portions ingested could send alerts when anomalies occur within daily regimens, medication timings & exercise activities performed, a much smoother system could indeed simplify life with Diabetes Type one considerably, reducing likelihoods of serious errors significantly!
To keep a healthy regime for diabetes maintenance you also may require some assistance of an assistant AI bot.

A Wearable That Never Runs Out Batterymeaning That Diabetics could Have A Continuous Monitor Without Running Back & For the Charger Each Morning #FutureTrends - Future Of Healthcare: What will healthcare look like in 2018 #HospTech #SmartWearables #ConnectedHealth #Digitalhealth#DiabetesTreatment #FitnessMotivation]
The potential application wearers offer the realm of tracking your blood sugars throughout one day's timeline and providing suggestions with food intake as needed has already led me closer towards my objective.

As long as wearable advancements keep getting refined so we continue seeing accurate results as possible to allow continuous learning then this area may unlock possibilities within my life of tackling the ongoing fight with DM Type!assistant

What a fantastic scenario you've outlined!
How close am i getting there though?
Having said that the data gained can be monitored online through specific accounts where it automatically tracks what meals we have consumed or if medication has been ingested.
I've heard instances where continuous glucose monitors provide constant input so as not miss those fluctuations.
Even considering this idea makes managing diabetese so much easier on both daily habits.

If integration to my digital tracker were attainably, It becomes easier than managing everything independently within our heads alone,
Forgetting or confusing my med dosage schedule will likely come few due these integrations of this emerging tech with personalized medicine.
Now if those could possibly pair seamlessly with smartphones it'd create so easy managing of insulin as to feel as smooth-running as possible!
I am quite excited how connected technologies enhance people's wellbeing.
Even a smartphone connected blood glucose tracker was helpful!
It really doesn't do justice when it comes to a proper integration.
But if these innovations took integration in their data into daily life managing diabetes it sure would be life changing for people worldwide struggling with this disease.
Integrating such data within existing monitoring systems enables more accurate information for decision-making.

In addition integrating these smart trackers into more holistic medical advice software that is accessible not only through smartphones and but through tablets computers or the actual health care practitioner stations this provides both patient doctor cooperation to be amplified with enhanced data sets all while ensuring those important routine medication moments are captured.

I believe technology has got quite significant prospects at this stage of its development #MonitoringTools #DigitalAge]
Another possible improvement using IoT and sensors within smart wearables could give medical teams a complete real-time scenario understanding better.This would let for a proactive measure in detecting or preventing hyper/hypoglycemia scenarios - A very exciting prospect!
One step beyond: an always connected smart-wearable could help individuals manage a diabetes plan in real-time!

Not only does it make things simpler while also making an immediate diagnosis regarding your health issues in that aspect possible, the fact is it takes into mind how your body reacts to whatever changes that happens which makes adjustments far better in understanding what diet is required according in to glucose trends over time.
Imagine a watch which never dies out as battery supply thus enabling diabetic individuals enjoy uninterrupted diabetic supervision, and this is a dream we need more soon!

]
I truly expect to see that wearable tech makes this progress and develops so far concerning monitoring sugar levels continuously all the time.
So with an IoT-based smart wearable linked directly into this tracking app, managing my daily regime as regards my sugar control levels just turned from complicated to convenient and reliable.
An intelligent smartwatch equipped seamlessly integrating all your essential data including those readings could truly be an answer towards making sure I take care of myself.

As long time tracking progresses, a feature that I wish developers add in future editions might offer meal preparation ideas that suit various sugar levels to allow it feel less tedious when managing.

Excellent insights about the struggles of managing diabetes!
It's fascinating to explore how technology, especially wearables, can revolutionize diabetes care.
Indeed, integrating wearable technology with diabetes management apps can be a game-changer for people with diabetes.

You're absolutely right, keeping track of diet, medication, and glucose levels can be overwhelming, and integrating wearable technology with diabetes management apps can revolutionize the way people with diabetes monitor their condition.
You've highlighted the importance of streamlining health management processes, especially when it comes to constant monitoring and medication schedules.
